sentence: In all of the panic of the last couple of weeks, and with traders and pundits seemingly fixated on events in China, there is one major American domestic success story that is being somewhat overlooked.
The construction business in America is booming.
There is growth on all levels and this morning’s ADP private jobs numbers confirmed that once again.
Once again construction was an important part of the monthly job growth, with around 17,000 jobs added in the sector.
It should go without saying that construction is, in the main, a purely domestic business.
With the exception of some multinational civil engineering firms, events overseas have no immediate effect on companies in the industry.
If there were to be a complete meltdown there would be some knock on effect, but for the near future, events in China have little bearing on American construction companies.
Those that smell a building bubble would argue that growth has been too fast too soon, and that a collapse is imminent.
I would normally have sympathy with the contrarian view of a booming business, but in this case there are several reasons to believe that there is a lot more to come.
First, construction is just now really catching up with other businesses.

Housing arguably caused the last recession and it took several years for the market to absorb the entire excess inventory from that time and for demand to pick up but now that that is happening, things are moving rapidly.
Secondly, rental costs for both housing and business space continue to rise.
The reluctance to buy that afflicted the entire market pushed many into renting, but as costs continue to rise, owning is looking increasingly attractive.
It makes no sense then that companies in that field have been dragged down in a selloff blamed on slowing Chinese growth, and that means that there are bargains to be had.
Homebuilder Toll Brothers (TOL), for example has declined around 14.5 percent in the last two weeks.
Some of that was down to a miss on earnings in that time, but the company has grown EPS consistently over the last year or so and forecasts had maybe gotten a little too optimistic as a result.
At a P/E of around 13, TOL looks seriously undervalued.
The other way to play the growth is by looking at building supply companies.
The big boys in that field, Lowe’s (LOW) and Home Depot (HD) are both trading at levels that represent about a 10 percent decline over the last two weeks.
The P/Es in these cases are less obviously attractive at around 17 and 18 respectively, but these companies continue to dominate their market.
If you doubt their ability to continue to do so I would suggest that you take a look at a three year chart for upstart rival Lumber Liquidators (LL).
It is not a pretty sight.
The search for value has been a theme of Market Musings this week.

When markets are trading with huge correlation and panic, rather than logic, seems to be driving the moves there is always something that gets caught up in the storm despite not being affected by whatever the excuse for the selling may be.
Construction related stocks would seem to fit that category.
Eventually the cyclical nature of the construction business will ensure that a downturn comes.
For now, though, that looks far enough away to make picking up stock in the industry’s big players look like a smart move.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
